There's not much to say about Half-Life 2: Episode One. Unlike Half-Life: Opposing Force and Blue Shift, which were more like optional side stories for HL1, Episode One is the direct continuation to the story of Half-Life 2 and is definitely worth playing, but it's very short. It has the same great gameplay as HL2, just in a more bite sized experience. Recommended if you played Half-Life 2, but don't expect a long game.

- Boringly terrible
- It's the worst thing a game can be: boring. It's greatest sin though has to be it's extremely repetitive filler scenarios. such as the Antlions, what fun they were. also boring door puzzles and escort segments. but hey its Valve they can do no wrong. 
- Best part was definitely stupid ai/npc's (mainly Alyx) in my way and not being able to move past them while getting f'ed by hostiles and having to wait for doors / the next area to open.  
 no coherent storyline just ambiguous and ambiguous =/= great (apparently).  
- No clear objectives (this isn't bad within itself just tedious) , so you will easily find yourself not quite knowing where you should go, but your gamer instincts kick in and just end up doing the tasks after exhausting everything in the zone. 
- its just a shame that so many circle jerk and think this is great bec meh Valve n shieet. 
- no wonder episodic titles failed.  
-tehe where that 3rd game at though.

This is a terrible game because it is the worst thing a game can be: simply not fun. A game should, by definition, be something that you enjoy, and this feels like a chore. A shooter game in which half the time you have nothing to shoot enemies with, either because you have no guns or you have no ammunition? Wow, what a great idea!

And the repetitiveness is just terrible. Just how many cars do I have to push into holes to stop an endless stream of antlions? That thing got old the moment it appeared, but no, they make you do it again and again.

So you say you don’t like doing the same stuff over and over again? Great, because we have an electronic door for which you have to find the switch somewhere in the pitch dark. And when you do it, there is another. And another. And another. Yeah, we are really lazy when building levels so guess what? There is a group of people you have to escort from A to B. And when you do it, go back to A, because there is another group to escort to B. Then you will have to do it again. And after that, guess what you have to do? That’s right, the same thing again. And then again, just for good measure.

Plus, present (or rather, absent) are the same things that plague the whole series: no map, no coherent storyline (lack of coherent story is spun to mean “ambiguous” and “ambiguous” is spun to somehow mean great), and often no clear objectives, so you will easily find yourself not quite knowing where you should go, while not quite knowing what to do and definitely not knowing why. Granted, the situation is better here than in the first Half-Life game, but worse than in Half-Life 2.

And during the whole time, the game offers you a giant middle finger from developers in the form of “witty” remarks from Alyx, in which she (or rather they) mock you for doing all the stupid repetitive things the game makes you do, while not having any of the things I mentioned in the above paragraph (Alyx, by the way, got extremely annoying extremely fast). “Too bad we don’t have a map”, Alyx says at one point; “Wow, this again”, at another; “Good thing you know what to do, Gordon” in a situation when you don’t know what to do, except that you should somehow stop the core from exploding. On the surface, I guess this is supposed to be tongue in cheek, but in reality it is a giant FU to the player. “See, we make you do stupid things in a lousy game; we make fun of you for doing it; and you are gonna love us and convince yourself that this is a great game.” And sadly, many people do.

Play this only if you got it for free and you hate yourself.

Dato curioso sobre el juego:

Para el desarrollo del Episodio 1, se decidió implementar una mejor tecnología artificial sobre Alyx; pero lo que pasa es que durante el juego nos encontramos solos en casi el 60% de la campaña, encontrándonos a Alyx en ocasiones muy pequeñas. Aunque eh de reconocer que la mejora es muy notoria en su inteligencia artificial.

Para finalizar, les recomiendo comprar está joyita en el paquete de juegos "Orange Box" y en las ofertas de temporada, porque fuera de estás puede que llegue a ser un poquito caro.

-10/10-
